body: @junrao Would you have time to review this?
Thanks for the patch. Just a minor comment. Otherwise, LGTM.
In security.html, in the examples, we still have a few places that use --allow-hosts, --operations, --deny-hosts. Could you fix those too?
Sorry for missing those, fixed.
@junrao Fixed the callback return type.

@ijuma and @harshach Based on the comments on the jira I think we need to decide if KerberosShortNamer should also implement PrincipalBuilder. I think it makes sense but in order for it to be reused even by authorizer it must implement PrincipalToLocal interface. Let me know your thoughts and I can make the changes accordingly.

LGTM (assuming tests pass), @gwenshap any chance you could review this? @fpj verified that this fixes the issue for him https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2850?focusedCommentId=15009790&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15009790
LGTM, I changed the Confluent system test jobs to use systemTestLibs instead of jar (cc @ewencp @granders). Any chance you could merge this @guozhangwang?
I'm still learning ducktape, but seems fine to me.
This needs to be rebased (if it's still relevant).
Do we really want to have all of this in `.gitignore`? Personally, I'd prefer to only have the ones that are relevant to Kafka.
@granders, I updated the JIRA status to reflect that this is waiting for review (and set Jun as the reviewer since you asked him for review).
@microwishing, can you please close this PR? It's been generated incorrectly.

Thanks for doing this. A few comments:
- Please fix the jetty version in the PR comment (you only upgraded to 9.2.x as 9.3.x requires Java 8)
- What brings the `objenesis` dependency? I assume we don't use it directly in our codebase?
- There's quite a few changes between lz4 1.2.0 and 1.3, it would be good to do some testing to make sure it doesn't cause issues like the recent Snappy woes we had (KAFKA-2421 also includes this change by the way).
- Is the Jackson upgrade binary compatible?

@fpj, How easy/hard is it to change `KafkaServerTestHarness` to be more security friendly? In my experience, having multiple harnesses can be a bit of a pain as they diverge when new features are added.

Thanks for the review @ijuma. See my responses below:
- Thanks for the Jetty reminder. I updated the commit message but not the comment in the PR.
- `objenesis` comes from `easymock` and I could not find any direct usage.
- Looking at [KAFKA-2421](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2421), this change is the same and fixes that issue. We could close [KAFKA-2421](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2421) when this is committed. The changes in 1.3 are listed [here](https://github.com/jpountz/lz4-java/blob/master/CHANGES.md#130). What additional tests do you think I should add? We didn't add any for the Snappy issue in [KAFKA-2308](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2308).
- Jacksons policy on Minor upgrades can be found [here](https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson/wiki/Jackson-Releases#general). It should be binary compatible.
LGTM

Thanks for updating the PR message (that's what the kafka-merge-pr.py script uses for the commit message).

KAFKA-2308 didn't update the Snappy library, it just updated our code as far as I can see. In KAFKA-2189, for example, Jun asked the reporter to test it in their cluster to verify it. Part of the problem is that our existing tests only check that messages can be compressed and then decompressed, we don't check if message size becomes larger, for example (which was the issue in KAFKA-2189). The number of changes in the new LZ4 release is pretty large and that concerned me a little:

https://github.com/jpountz/lz4-java/compare/1.2.0...1.3.0

Ideally, we'd either improve our tests or run the branch in an existing cluster to verify that it's all good.

In any case, I started a system test build for your branch:

http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/198/

@ijuma Adding tests to verify no regression in compression size is a great idea. I will make a new Jira/PR to add those tests. If we pull in that PR first well be sure there is no impact on compression size with this change.
@granthenke great. One other option is to move the lz4 update to that branch too (which would unblock this PR as the other dependencies seem to be less of an issue).
Test failure is unrelated as I didn't change any code in this PR.
@ijuma Sounds good, I will move that work to  KAFKA-2421.
@ijuma I created #552 for the lzo change and unit test

Not sure why that one isn't showing up in the nightly trunk tests, but it is unrelated.
LGTM.
@granders Before we increase the timeout, it would be useful to figure out the exact cause. If the failure happens again, could you attach the log either in this jira or KAFKA-2827?
LGTM.
@granders, @guozhangwang: I added some bounce tests and addressed Geoff's comments. Unless there are any concerns, this is probably ready to merge whenever there is a good opportunity.

Closing PR as requested at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-10795

@granders @guozhangwang mind taking a look?
LGTM.

I tested this by setting `log_level = "TRACE"` in `mirror_maker.py` and running the following test with and without the update to `tools-log4j.properties`:

```
ducktape tests/kafkatest/tests/mirror_maker_test.py::TestMirrorMakerService.test_simple_end_to_end --parameters '{"new_consumer": false}'
```

TRACE level logging is visible in mirror maker log with this change, but only DEBUG level logging is visible without it, which is expected.
Replication test passes on EC2 too: http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/209/console
Yeah, but the whole point is to pass on local machine...

@granders Should we get rid of other instances of this?

```
$ git grep [.]Threshold
tests/kafkatest/services/performance/templates/tools_log4j.properties:log4j.appender.FILE.Threshold=debug
tests/kafkatest/services/templates/connect_log4j.properties:log4j.appender.FILE.Threshold=debug
tests/kafkatest/services/templates/tools_log4j.properties:log4j.appender.FILE.Threshold=debug
```

Yep - the EC2 reading was just to confirm it does actually run there without issue too. I'm running the below locally. If you let me know where you hit a problem I can investigate further:

```
$ hub checkout https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/520
...
$ ./gradlew clean jar
...
$ ducktape --version
0.3.8

$ ducktape tests/kafkatest/tests/replication_test.py
```

@edenhill, can you please check the latest version? I also changed the client example as the idea is to have one principal per OS user and we cannot have more than one JAAS file per JVM, so for cases where there is a producer and consumer in the same machine, it's just easier to have a single principal/JAAS file.
Thanks @rajinisivaram. @granders, can you please review this?
Thanks @rajinisivaram. @guozhangwang, could you please review this? We are getting a number of failures that seem related to this issue.

Getting the discussion stared on ScalaStyle. This pull request only contains the integration to gradle and the configuration of the proposed scalastyle rules. Once this is reviewed and the rules are agreed upon and I can add a commit with the changes to make the build pass and reduce the noise from some of the ones we want to enable but can't yet.
@junrao Can you please merge this if you're happy with the latest changes (based on feedback from Magnus)?
LGTM

The latest run of jenkins had a test failure that failed with the following message:

```
kafka.common.TopicExistsException: Topic "topic" already exists.
```

Is it possible that the the test here is leaking into `SslProducerSendTest`? I checked and it seems to be closing everything, but just in case I have changed the topic name here from `topic` to `e2etopic`.
@fpj, I think that's https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/399

These ignore rules should technically be included in your users .gitignore since they are more related to your environment than the project. That said to simplify things, overtime, some common environmental ignore rules have been added to the Kafka repo. I agree with adding them to the repository/root .gitignore file, but there definitely should not be a file for each module. 

Please see my pull request and discussion with @ijuma on the topic here: #479. I think your case should be covered.
@ewencp Aha! Very good point sir

Thanks @granthenke 
Agree.
I have add a global rules "gitignore" file and using recommendations from GitHub: https://help.github.com/articles/ignoring-files/

OK, since it solves the issue for you and didn't cause new problems, I'll commit.

I think the local virtual-box tests have a lot more problems though...
This is not a huge deal since its only in test dependencies. But since we publish test jars in maven and the fix is easy...I figure we should fix it.
@gwenshap Trivial fix for an extremely frustrating typo (that I know has caught @granders and just caught me as well).
LGTM

mmmm... good thing I didn't notice this file exists :)

unrelated to this PR, but I had to comment out this part in order to start vagrant with AWS:
Object.const_get("VagrantPlugins").const_get("HostManager").const_get("HostsFile").class_eval do
  alias_method :old_update_guest, :update_guest
  def update_guest(machine)
    state_id = machine.state.id
    return if state_id == :not_created || state_id == :stopped
    old_update_guest(machine)
  end
end

Otherwise it would complain about missing method.

Did you run into anything like this? Or do you know why this is even necessary?

@gwenshap There's a comment above that code that explains it:

```
# This is a horrible hack to work around bad interactions between
# vagrant-hostmanager and vagrant-aws/vagrant's implementation. Hostmanager
# wants to update the /etc/hosts entries, but tries to do so even on nodes that
# aren't up (e.g. even when all nodes are stopped and you run vagrant
# destroy). Because of the way the underlying code in vagrant works, it still
# tries to communicate with the node and has to wait for a very long
# timeout. This modifies the update to check for hosts that are not created or
# stopped, skipping the update in that case since it's impossible to update
# nodes in that state.
```

Although understanding all that might require knowing more about the Vagrant setup -- hostmanager is a plugin that fills in /etc/hosts with info for other nodes so you can use convenient names like `worker1` rather than IP addresses.

Unfortunately, this was the way I could hack around the bad interaction w/ vagrant-aws, but is also quite brittle. You might want to check the versions of your vagrant plugins. I think we specify ranges of versions that will work in the README, and there's a bootstrapping script that should also ensure you have the right versions.

The annoying complexity of the Vagrantfile combined with the fact that most Vagrant stuff does not parallelize well makes me wonder if we should move some of the responsibility for handling these steps over to the ducktape VagrantCluster class, but I also don't want to end up reimplementing significant chunks of Vagrant's existing functionality...

@gwenshap This is a blocker, also should be a quick review. Should trivially apply to 0.9.0 branch as well.

@junrao Just pinging you to make sure you see this -- this should be the fix to the issue I found that would block RC4.

Also, ran the relevant system tests here: http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/216 I also ran this a bunch of times on my own AWS cluster and it passed, whereas I was able to pretty regularly reproduce the issue before the patch.
Thanks @rajinisivaram, this looks good to me

The latest build failed for with the same error:

```
kafka.common.TopicExistsException: Topic "topic" already exists.
```

This time it can't be the changes here because the test cases here don't create "topic".

Alas these tests don't seem to pass locally in virtual box (at least for me). I've had a similar problem with PR #496 which I'm looking at at the moment. These are quite likely related from what I can tell.
Looks good to me. It's a relatively complicated test setup so I wonder if it's worth adding a comment describing what's going on. A minor thought though.
LGTM.

@benstopford agreed, that's part of the reason I initially introduced another test harness class. It wasn't trivial to work with the existing classes, so I had to juggle with the code a bit to make it work. But, at the same time, I doesn't make a lot of sense to keep creating test harness classes, we already have a few, so I ended up shuffling some code and adding some knobs to get the new tests to work with `IntegrationTestHarness` and `SaslTestHarness`. I'll add some description to it, it is a good suggestion.

@rajinisivaram If you reduce the throughput of the producer it will stabilise it in virtualbox. 
`self.producer_throughput = 1000`
This PR now passes in VB @gwenshap can you please merge
@benstopford Thank you, should I reduce this in the test? Also, is the change required only for non-PLAINTEXT?
Nice. :)

@rajinisivaram Yes just reducing the value in the constructor (L98) should suffice. The problem actually has nothing to do with protocol. It's to do with the upgrade to the new consumer. I'm not yet clear exactly why this happens but basically the verifiable producer becomes overwhelmed and goes offline for up to a couple of minutes. Reducing the throughput in the producer solves the problem. 

If you don't have a VB setup (and you don't want one) I can run this test in VB for you later on if you like.
@benstopford I have committed the change to producer throughput. I dont have a VB setup, so I would appreciate your help in testing on VB when you have some time and your setup is free. Many thanks.
